title: IDOR in semrush academy
vulnerability_information:
#INTRODUCTION
    
##_I used two accounts to search for this vulnerability:_
- id: 5410425 email: â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ-2@anosimple.com
- id: 5407773 email: â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ@anosimple.com

##_IP used:_
â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ

##_Endpoint URL:_
https://www.semrush.com/academy/courses/userEnroll

#EXPLOITATION

##_Description of Security Issue:_
When a user clicks on the "Enroll for free" button in the course pages such as here https://www.semrush.com/academy/library/courses?spec=ALL&lang=en-US, the client makes a request like this: {F696872}.
This page registers the user to the course and returns information concerning the user and the course.
The problem lies in the fact that the server does not verify the userId belongs to the user making the request, so an attacker can pretend to be someone else by modifying the userId with that of the victim.

##_Steps needed to reproduce bug:_
1.Login to your account
2.Go to https://www.semrush.com/academy/library/courses?spec=ALL&lang=en-US
3.On burp suit, press the intercept button on
4.Click on the button "Enroll for free" on a random course
5.Forward the requests until you find this POST request: {F696872}
6.Change the userId with that of the victim and send the request
7.The request has been processed by the server

#RESOLUTION
Check that the userId belongs to the person who registers to the course.

## Impact

##_Number of people concerned:_
The bug affects all semrush academy users.

##_Exploit scenario for this vulnerability:_
An attacker can scrap semrush academy in order to have all the existing courseId or choose a particular course and recover his courseId.
Thereafter either the attacker already knows the victim's userId or he can bruteforce the userId field.
The attacker can then register a user for any course he wishes.
The attacker can also deduce according to the value of "creationDate" if the user has registered for the course or not and when.
The attacker also has access to other variables such as "engagement", "status", "userEngagement", etc...
vulnerability_information_html:
INTRODUCTION

I used two accounts to search for this vulnerability:

  • id: 5410425 email: â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ-2@anosimple.com
  • id: 5407773 email: â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ@anosimple.com

IP used:

â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ

Endpoint URL:

https://www.semrush.com/academy/courses/userEnroll

EXPLOITATION

Description of Security Issue:

When a user clicks on the "Enroll for free" button in the course pages such as here https://www.semrush.com/academy/library/courses?spec=ALL&lang=en-US, the client makes a request like this: .
This page registers the user to the course and returns information concerning the user and the course.
The problem lies in the fact that the server does not verify the userId belongs to the user making the request, so an attacker can pretend to be someone else by modifying the userId with that of the victim.

Steps needed to reproduce bug:

1.Login to your account
2.Go to https://www.semrush.com/academy/library/courses?spec=ALL&lang=en-US
3.On burp suit, press the intercept button on
4.Click on the button "Enroll for free" on a random course
5.Forward the requests until you find this POST request:
6.Change the userId with that of the victim and send the request
7.The request has been processed by the server

RESOLUTION

Check that the userId belongs to the person who registers to the course.

Impact

Number of people concerned:

The bug affects all semrush academy users.

Exploit scenario for this vulnerability:

An attacker can scrap semrush academy in order to have all the existing courseId or choose a particular course and recover his courseId.
Thereafter either the attacker already knows the victim's userId or he can bruteforce the userId field.
The attacker can then register a user for any course he wishes.
The attacker can also deduce according to the value of "creationDate" if the user has registered for the course or not and when.
The attacker also has access to other variables such as "engagement", "status", "userEngagement", etc...

activities.message:
Hello, please provide a proper way how to find a users Id and chain this to a valid vulnerability.
In your PoC you use already known users id

activities.message:
Hi,
We can bruteforce the user Id or use social engineering.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,
We can bruteforce the user Id or use social engineering.

activities.message: By scrapping and brute-force the entries an attacker would be able to establish a list of the courses taken by each person at semrush academy as well as the date on which they started the course. An attacker will also be able to draw from the userId list that he will have established by bruteforcing in order to register them in the course of his choice.
activities.markdown_message: By scrapping and brute-force the entries an attacker would be able to establish a list of the courses taken by each person at semrush academy as well as the date on which they started the course. An attacker will also be able to draw from the userId list that he will have established by bruteforcing in order to register them in the course of his choice.

activities.message:
Hi, @a_d_a_m ! The userId field is difficult to brute-force because of high entropy. So, based on your initial description, there do not appear to be any security implications as a direct result of this behavior. 
If you disagree, please reply with additional information describing your reasoning. Including a working proof-of-concept can be incredibly helpful in our assessment of these claims.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi, @a_d_a_m ! The userId field is difficult to brute-force because of high entropy. So, based on your initial description, there do not appear to be any security implications as a direct result of this behavior.
If you disagree, please reply with additional information describing your reasoning. Including a working proof-of-concept can be incredibly helpful in our assessment of these claims.

activities.message:
Hello and thank you for your reply.
Indeed it is difficult to brute-force the userId field but not impossible, I noticed some similarity in the userId that I could observe and I do not think that this is due to hasard.
An attacker still has a good chance of succeeding in extracting userId with for example the use of botnet and by providing a model which is often found in userId.
I have, moreover, indicate as you can see in this capture that the complexity of the attack is high to calculate severity.
In any case this remains a misconfiguration, the fact that an attacker connecting from another account can alter and access data from another account "just" with a userId.
There are lots of relative scenarios that allow an attacker to use this vulnerability.
If an attacker manages to access another person's userId for many possible reasons then he will have permanent control over him because we cannot change our userId.
The fact of being able to do this "simply" by changing the userId is not secure and this remains a vulnerability since the reference to the object is not secure.
I hope you will understand my point of view!
Thank you :) !
activities.markdown_message:
Hello and thank you for your reply.
Indeed it is difficult to brute-force the userId field but not impossible, I noticed some similarity in the userId that I could observe and I do not think that this is due to hasard.
An attacker still has a good chance of succeeding in extracting userId with for example the use of botnet and by providing a model which is often found in userId.
I have, moreover, indicate as you can see in this capture that the complexity of the attack is high to calculate severity.
In any case this remains a misconfiguration, the fact that an attacker connecting from another account can alter and access data from another account "just" with a userId.
There are lots of relative scenarios that allow an attacker to use this vulnerability.
If an attacker manages to access another person's userId for many possible reasons then he will have permanent control over him because we cannot change our userId.
The fact of being able to do this "simply" by changing the userId is not secure and this remains a vulnerability since the reference to the object is not secure.
I hope you will understand my point of view!
Thank you :) !
